Troubles of conscience, and a wretched ende,
Bring thee vnto a poore forgotten graue.
My being: for another tongue to tell it,
Cease, a mother! some good man that dares
Speake for his King and Countrey: I am full
Of too much womans pittie: yet ô Heauen,
Since it concernes the safety of my soueraigne
Let it not be a cruelty in mee
Nor draw a Mothers name in question,
Amongst vnborne people, to giue vp that man:
To law and Iustice that vnrighteously
Has sought his fathers death: be dease, be dease Syr,
Your Sonne is the Offendor, Now haue you all,
Would I might neuer speake againe.
My Sonne? Heauen helpe mee.
No more I thought it: and since
His life is growne so dangerous: Let them that
Gaue him, take him: Hee shall dye,
And with him all my feares.
O vse your mercie: you haue a braue subiect
To bestowe it on, Ile forgiue him Syr: and for his
Wrong to mee, Ile be before yee.
Durst his villenie extend to thee?
Nothing but heates of youth Syr.
Vppon my life hee sought my Bed.
I must confesse he loued mee:
Somewhat beyond a Sonne, and still pursude it
With such a Lust: I will not say Ambition,
That cleane forgetting all obedience,
And onely following his first heate vnto mee,
Hee hotely fought your death, and me in Marriage.
O Villaine!
But I forget all: and am halfe ashamde
To presse a man so farre.
Where is the Duke? for Gods sake bring me to him.
Here I am; Each corner of the Dukedome
Sends new affrights forth: what wouldst thou speake?
I cannot Sir, my feare tyes vp my tongue.
Why, whats the matter? Take thy courage
To thee; and boldly speake, where are the Guard?
In the Gods name, cut with it:
Treason, treason.
In whome?
Double the Guard.
There is a fellow Syr.
Leaue shaking man.
'Tis not for feare, but wonder. Leon. Well.
There is a fellow Syr, close ith Lobby:
You othe Guarde, looke to the dore there.
But let me knowe the businesse.
O that the hearts of men shuld be so hardned
Against so good a Duke, for Gods sake Syr,
Seeke meanes to saue your selfe, This wretched slaue
Has his sword in his hand, I knowe his heart:
Oh it hath almost killd mee with the thought of it.

sp.speaker: Leon.

lg.l: Where is hee?

sp.stage: Enter the Guard, and bring him in.

lg.l: The Lobby Syr, close in a corner:
Looke to your selues, for Heauens sake,
Mee thinkes hee is here already.
Fellowes of the Guard be valiant.
Goe sirs, and apprehend him; Treason shall
Neuer dare mee in mine owne Gates.

sp.speaker: Tim.

lg.l: Tis done.

sp.stage: There they bring the Prince in.

lg.l: And thou shalt finde it to thy best content.
Are these the comforts of my Age?
Theyre happy that ende theyr dayes Contented
With a little, and liue aloofe from dangers, to a King
Euery coutent doth a newe; perill bring.
O let mee liue no longer, shame of Nature,
Bastard to Honour: Traytor, Murderer,
Diuell in a humane shape, A way with him,
Hee shall not breath his hote infection here.
Syr heare mee.
Am I or hee your Duke? away with im
To a close prison: your Highnes now shall know,
Such branches must be cropt before they growe,
What euer Fortune comes, I bid it welcome,
My innocencie is my Armor: Gods preserue you.
Fare thee well. I shal neuer see so braue a Gentl:
Would I could weepe out his offences.
Or I would weeepe out mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Leon.

lg.l: Come Gentlemen, weele determine presently
About his death: wee cannot be too forward in our
Safety: I am very sick, leade me vnto my Bed.

sp.stage: Exeunt. Enter Cittizen and his Boye.

sp.speaker: Cittizen.
sp.p: Syrrha, go fetch my Foxe from the Cutlers: Theres money for the scowring: Tell him, I stoppe a Grote since the last great Muster: Hee had in store Pitch for the bruze. He tooke with the Recoyling of his Gunne.

lg.l: Yes Syr.

sp.speaker: Cittiz.
sp.p: And doe you heare? when yu come, Take downe my Buckler, and sweepe the Copwebs off: and Grinde the picke out, and fetch a Naile or two: and Tacke on bracers: your Mistris made a potlid ont, I thanke her at her Mayds wedding, and burnt off the Handle.

lg.l: I will Syr.

sp.speaker: Cittiz.
sp.p: Whoe's within heere, hoe Neighbour, not styrring yet?

lg.l: O God morrow, god morrowe: what
Newes, what newes?
It holdes, he dyes this morning.
Then happy man be his fortune, I am resolude,
And so am I, and 40. more good fellowes
That wil not giue their heads for the washing, I take it.

sp.speaker: 2. Cittiz.
sp.p: Sfoote man, who would not hang in such Good companie, and such a cause? A Fire a Wife and Children, Tis such a Iest that men should looke behinde em to the world: And let theyr honours, their honours Neighbour slip.

lg.l: Ile giue thee a pinte of Bastard and a rolle For that bare word,
They say that we Taylors, are things that
Laye one another, and our Geese hatche vs: Ile make some of vm feele they are Geese ath game then,
Ifack take down my Bill, tis ten to one I vse it, Take a
Good heart man, all the low ward is ours, with a wett
Finger.
And lay my Cut-fingred Gantlet ready for mee,
That that I vsed to worke in, when the Gentl: were
Vp against vs, a beaten out of towne, and almost out a
Debt to, for a plague on vm, they neuer paid wel since,
And take heede sirrah: your mistris heares not of this
Businesse, shees neere her time: yet if shee doe,
I care not, shee may long for Rebellion,
For shee has a diuellish spirite,
Come, lets call vp the new Ircmonger, is as
Tough as steele, & has a fine wit in these resurrections:
Are you stirring Neighbour?
O Good morrowe Neighbours,
Ile come to you presently.
Go too, this is his Mothers doing: shees a Polecat.
As any is in the world.

sp.p: Then say I haue hit it, and a vengeance on her, let her be what she will.
Amen say I, shee has brought things to a fine passe with her wisedome, doe you marke it?

One thing I am sure she has, the good old Duke she giues him pappe againe they say, and dandles him, and hangs a corrall and bells about his necke, and makes him beleeue his teeth will come agen; which if they did, and I he, I would worry her as neuer curre was worried: I would neighbour till my teeth met I know where, but thats counsell.
Good morrow neighbours: heare you the sadde newes?

lg.l: Yes, would we knew as well how to preuent it.

sp.p: I cannot tell, me thinks twere no great matter, if men were men: but—

lg.l: You do not twit me with my calling neighbor?

sp.p: No surely: for I know your spirit to be tall, pray be not vext.

Pray forward with your counsell:
I am what I am, and they that proue me, shall finde me to their cost: do you marke mee neighbour, to their cost I say.

lg.l: Nay looke how soone you are angry.
They shall neighbours: yes, I say they shall.
I doe beleeue they shall.
I know they shall.
Whether you doe or no I care not two-pence,
I am no beast, I know mine owne strength neighbors;
God blesse the King, your companies is fayre.

sp.p: Nay neighbour now yee erre, I must tell you so and yee were twentie neighbours,

lg.l: You had best goe peach, doe, peach.
Peach, I scorne the motion.

sp.p: Doe, and see what followes: Ile spend an hundred pound, and be two I care not, but Ile vndo thee.
Peach, ô disgrace: peach in thy face, and doe the worst thou canst: I am a true man, and a free-man peach!

lg.l: Nay looke, you will spoyle all.
Peach!

sp.p: Whilst you two brawle together, the Prince will lose his life.
Come, giue me your hand, I loue you well, are you for the action.

lg.l: Yes: but peach prouokes me, tis a cold fruit,
I feele it cold in my stomacke still.
No more, Ile giue you cake to disgest it.

sp.p: Shut vp my shop, and bee ready at a call boyes, and one of you runne ouer my olde tucke with a few ashes, tis growne odious with tosting cheese: and burne a little giniper in my murrin, the maide made it her chamber-pot, an houre hence Ile come againe; and as you here from me, send me a cleane shirt.

lg.l: The Chandler by the wharfe, and it be thy will.
Gossip good morrow.

sp.p: O good morrow Gossip: good morrow all, I see wee of one minde you cleaue so close together: come tis time, I haue prepared a hundred if they stand.

lg.l: Tis well done: shall we seuer, and about it?

sp.p: First lets to the Tauerne, and a pynt a peece will make vs Dragons.

lg.l: I will haue no mercy, come what will of it.

sp.p: If my tucke hold Ile spit the Guard like Larks with sage betweene em.
I haue a foolish bil to reckon with em, wil make some of their hearts ake, and Ile lay it on: now shall I fight, twill doe you good to see me.
Come Ile do something for the Towne to talke of when I am rotten: pray God there bee enough to kill, thats all.

lg.l: How blacke the day begins!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Can you blame it, and looke vpon such a deed as shall be done this morning?

lg.l: Does the Prince suffer to day?
Within this houre they say.

sp.speaker: Agen.
sp.p: Well, they that are most wicked are most safe: twill be a strange Iustice and a lamentable, gods keepe vs from the too soone feeling of it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I care not if my throat were next: for to liue still, and liue heere, were but to growe fat for the Shambles.

sp.speaker: Nis.
sp.p: Yet we must doe it, and thanke em too, that our liues may be accepted.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.p: Faith Ile go starue my selfe, or grow diseas'd to shame the hangman; for I am sure hee shall be my Herald, and quarter me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I a plague on him, hee's too excellent at armes.

sp.speaker: Nisus.
sp.p: Will you goe see this sadde sight my Lord Agenor?

lg.l: Ile make a mourner.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If I could doe him any good I would goe, The bare sight else will but afflict my spirit, my prayers shall be as neere him as your eyes: As you finde him setled, remember my loue and seruice to his Grace.

lg.l: We will weepe for ioy sir, farewell.
Farewel to all our happinesse, a long farewel.
Thou angry power, whether of heauen or hell,
That layst this sharpe correction on our Kingdome
For our offences, infinite and mighty,
O heare me, and at length be pleas'd, be pleas'd
With pitty to draw backe thy vengeance,
Too heauy for our weaknesse; and accept,
(Since it is your discretion, heauenly Wisedomes,
To haue it so) this sacrifice for all,
That now is flying to your happinesse,
Onely for you most fit: let all our sinnes suffer in him.
Gods, whats the matter! I hope tis ioy.
How now my Lords?
Ile tell you with that little breath I haue;
More ioy then you dare thinke, The Prince is safe from
Danger.
How!
Tis true, and thus it was; His houre was come
To lose his life, he ready for the stroke,
Nobly, and full of Saint-like patience,
Went with his Guard: which when the people saw,
Compassion first went out, mingled with teares,
That bred desires, and whispers to each other,
To doe some worthy kindnes for the Prince.
And ere they vnderstood well how to doe,
Fury stept in, and taught them what to doe,
Thrusting on euery hand to rescue him,
As a white innocent: then flew the rore
Through all the streetes, of Saue him, saue him, saue him;
And as they cryde, they did for catching vp
Such sudden weapons as their madnesse shew them.
In short, they beat the Guard, & tooke him from em,
And now march with him like a royall Army.
Heauen, heauen I thanke thee,
What a slaue was I to haue my hand so farre from
This braue rescue, 'tad beene a thing to bragge on
When I was olde. Shall we runne for a wager to the
Next Temple and giue thanks?

sp.speaker: Nis.

lg.l: As fast as wishes.

sp.stage: Enter Leucippus and Ismenus: the people within stoppes.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Good friends goe home againe, there's not a man shall goe with me.

lg.l: Will you not take reuenge? I le call them on.
All that loue me depart:
I thanke you, and will serue you for your loues:
But I will thanke you more to suffer me
To gouerne em once: more, I doe beg yee,
For my sake to your houses.
Gods preserue you.
And what house will you goe too?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ismenus I will take the wariest courses that I can thinke of to defend my selfe, but not offend.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: You may kill your mother, and neuer offend your father an honest man.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Thou knowst I can scape now, thats all I looke for: Ile leaue.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p:
Tima. a pox take him, would I had him here, I would kill him at his owne weapon single sithes wee
haue built inough on him: plague ont, Ime out of all patience: discharge such an Army as this, that would haue followed you without paying, ô gods!

lg.l: To what end should keepe em? I am free.

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.p: Yes, free o'th Traytors, for you are proclaymed one.

lg.l: Should I therefore make my selse one?
This is one of your morall Philosophy is it?
Heauen blesse me from subtilties to vndo my self with;
But I know if, reason her selfe were here,
She would not part with her owne safetie.
Well, pardon Ismenus, for I know
My courses are most iust; nor will I staine em
With one bad action: for thy selfe, thou knowst,
That though I may command thee, I shall be
A ready seruant to thee if thou needst: and so Ile
Take my leaue.
of whome?
Of thee.
Heart, you shall take no leaue of me.
Shall I not?

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: No by the gods shall you not: nay if you haue no more wit but to goe obsolutely alone, Ile bee in a little.

lg.l: Nay prethee good Ismenus part with me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: I wonnot yfaith, neuer moue it any more; for by this good light I wonnot.

lg.l: This is an ill time to be thus vnruly:
Ismenus you must leaue me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Yes if you can beat me away: else, the gods refuse me if I will leaue you till I see more reason; you sha'nt vndoe your selfe.

lg.l: But why wilt not leaue me?

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p:
Why Ile tell you, Because when you are gone, then— life, if I haue not forgot my reason— heele take mee: you put mee out of patience so: O!
marry when you are gone, then will your Mother: a pox confound her, she neuer comes in my head but she spoiles my memory to: there are a hundred reasons.

lg.l: But shew me one.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Shew you, what a stirre here is, why I will shew you: Doe you thinke; well, well, I know what I know, I pray come, come. Tis in vaine: but I am sure. Diuels take em, what doe I meddle with em? You know your selfe. Soule, I thinke I am: is there any man ith world? as if you knew not this already better then I. Pish, pish, I le giue no reason.

lg.l: But I will tell thee one why thou shouldst stay:
I haue not one friend in the Court but thou,
On whom I may be bold to trust to send mee
Any intelligence: and if thou lou'st me
Thou wilt doe this, thou needst not feare to stay,
For there are new-come Proclamations out;
Where all are pardoned but my selfe.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Tis true, and in the same Proclamation your fine sister Vrania, whome you vs'd so kindly, is preclaymd heyre apparant to the Crowne.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.p: What though, thou mayst stay at home without danger.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Danger, hang danger, what tell you mee of danger?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Why if thou wilt not do't, I think thou dar'st not.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: I dare not: if you speake it in earnest, you are a boy.

lg.l: Well fir, if you dare, let me see you do't.
Why so you shall, I will stay.
Why God a mercy.
You know I loue you but too well.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Now take these few directions: farewell, send to me by the wariest wayes thou canst: I haue a soule tells me we shall meete often. The gods protect thee.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Poxe o'me selfe for an Asse, I me crying now, God be with you, if I neuer see you againe: why then pray get you gone, for griefe and anger wonnot let me know what I say. Ile to the Court as fast as I can, and see the new heyre apparant.

lg.l: What hast thou sound him?
Madame he is comming in.
Gods blesse my brother where so ere he is:
And I you keepe me fro the bed
Of any naughtie Tyrant whom my mother
Would ha me haue to wrong him.
What would her new Grace haue with me?
Leaue vs a while. My Lord Ismenus,
I pray for the loue of heauen and God,
That you would tell me one thing, which I know
You can doe weele.
Wheres her faine Grace?
You know me weel inough, but that you mock,
I am she my sen.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: God blesse him that shall bee thy husband, if thou wearst breeches thus soone, thoult bee as impudent as thy mother.

lg.l: But will you tell me this one thing?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: What ist? if it be no great matter whether I doe or no, perhaps I will.

lg.l: Yes faith tis matter.
And what ist?
I pray you let we know whaire the Prince my brother is.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I faith you shan be hangd first, is your mother so foolish to thinke your good Grace can sift it out of me?

sp.speaker: Vrania.
sp.p: If you haue any mercy left i'you to a poore wench tell me.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Why wouldst not thou haue thy braines beat out for this, to follow thy mothers steps so young?

lg.l: But beleeue me, she knowes none of this.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Beleeue you? why do you thinke I neuer had wits? or that I am runne out of them? how should it belong to you to know, If I could tell?

lg.l: Why I will tell you: and if I speake false
Let the Diuell ha me, Yonders a bad man,
Come from a Tayrant to my mother, and what name
They ha for him, good faith I cannot tell.
An Embassador.
Thats it: but he would carry me away,
And haue me marry his Master; and Ile day
Ere I will ha him.
But whats this to knowing where the Prince is?
Yes, for you know all my mother does:
Agen the Prince is but to ma me great.
Pray, I know that too well, what ten?
Why I would goe to the good Marquesse my
Brother, and put my selfe into his hands, that so
He may preserue himselfe.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: O that thou hadst no seede of thy Mother in thee, and couldst meane this now.

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Why feth I do, wou'd I might nere stirre more if I doe not.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I shall proue a ridiculous foole, Ile be damnd else: hang me if I doe not halfe beleeue thee.

lg.l: By my troth you may.
By my troth I doe: I know Ime an Asse fort,
But I cannot helpe it.
And won you tell me then?
Yes faith will I, or any thing else ith world, for
I think thou art as good a creature as euer was borne.
But aile goe i'this ladst reparrell:
But you mun helpe me to Siluer.

sp.speaker: Ismenus.
sp.p: Helpe thee: why the Poxe take him that will not helpe thee to any thing ith world; Ile helpe thee to Mony, and Ile doe't presently to, and yet soule, If you should play the scuruie Harlotrie little pockie baggage now and couzen mee, what then?

lg.l: Why, an I do, woud I might nere see day agen.
Nay by this light I do not thinke thou wilt:
Ile presently prouide thee mony and a letter.

sp.speaker: Ura.

lg.l: I but Ile nere deliuer it.
When I haue found my Brother, I will begge
To serue him; but he shall neuer kno who I am;
For he must hate me then for my badde mother:
Ile say I am a countrey Lad that want a seruice,
And haue streid on him by chance, lest he discouer me;
I know I must not liue long, but that taime
I ha to spend, shall be in seruing him.
And though my Mother seeke to take his life away,
In ai day my brother shall be taught that I was
Euer good, though she were naught.

sp.stage: Enter Bacha and Timantus: Bacha reading a Letter.

lg.l: Runne away, the diuell be her guide.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Faith shees gone: theres a Letter I found it in her pocket, would I were with her, shees a hansome Lady, a plague vpon my bashfulnes, I had bobd her long agoe else.

lg.l: What a base Whore is this, that after all
My wayes for her aduancement, should so poorely make vertue her vndoer, and choose this time,
The King being deadly sicke: and I intending
A present marriage with some forraigne Prince,
To strengthen and secure my selfe. She writes here
Like a wise Gentle woman; She will not stay:
And the example of her deare brother, makes her
Feare her selfe, to whome shee meanes to flye.
Why, who can helpe it?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now pouertie and Leacherie which is thy end, rot thee, where ere to goest with all thy goodnes.

sp.speaker: Timan.
sp.p: Berlady theyle bruze her: and shee weare a brasse. I am sure theyle breake stone walles: I hane had experience of them both, and they haue made me desperate: but theres a Messenger Madam come from the Prince with a Letter to Ismenus, who by him returnes an answere.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: This comes as pat as wishes: thou shalt presently away Timantus.

lg.l: Whither Madame?
To the Prince, and take the Messenger for guide.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What shall I doe there? I haue done too much mischiefe to be beleeued againe, or indeede, to scape with my head on my backe if I be once knowne.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Thou art a weake shallow foole: get thee a disguise, and withall, when thou comst before him, haue a Letter faind to deliuer him; and then, as thou hast euer hope of goodnes by me, or after me, strike one home stroke that shall not neede another: dar'st thou speake, dar'st thou? if thou fal'st off, goe bee a Rogue a againe, and lye and Pander to procure thy meate: darst thou speake to me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sure I shall neuer walke when I am dead. I haue no spirit Madame, Ile bee drunke but Ile doe it, thats all my refuge.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Away, no more, then Ile rayse an Army whilst the King yet liues, if all the meanes and power I haue can doe it I cannot tell.

lg.l: Are you inuenting still? weele ease your studies.
Why how now sawcy Lords?
Nay Ile shake yee, yes diuell, I will shake yee.
Doe not you know me Lords?
Yes deadly sin we know ye, would we did not.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Doe you heare Whore, a plague a God vpon thee, the Duke is dead.

lg.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I, wild-fire and brimstone take thee: good man hee is dead, and past those miseries which thou, salt infection-like, like a disease, flungst vpon his head. Doft thou heare, and twere not more respect in Woman-hood in generall then thee, because I had a Mother, who I will not say shee was good, shee liu'd so neere thy time, I would haue thee in vengeance of this man, whose peace is made in heauen by this time, tyde to a post, and dryde ith sunne, and after carryed about and shone at fayres for money, with a long storie of the diuell thy father that taught thee to be whorish, enuious, bloudy.

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: You fleering harlot, Ile haue a horse to leape thee, and thy base issue shall carry Sumpters. Come Lords, bring her along, weele to the Prince all, where her hell-hood shall waite his censure; and if he spare thee she Goat, may he lye with thee againe; and beside, mayst thou vpon him some nastie foule disease that hate still followes, and his end, a dry ditch. Leade you corrupted whore, or Ile draw gode shall make you skippe: away to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I hope yet I shall come too late to finde him.
sp.stage: Enter Loucippus, Vrana,: Leu, with a bloudy handkercher.

lg.l: Alas poore boy, why dost thou follow me?
What canst thou hope for? I am poore as thou art.
In good feth I shall be weell and rich enough
If you will loue me, and not put me from you.
Why dost thou choose out me boy to vndo thee?
Alas, for pitty take another Master,
That may be able to deserue thy loue
In breeding thee hereafter: me thou knowst not
More then my misery: and therefore canst not
Looke for rewards at my hands: would I were able,
My pretty knaue, to doe thee any kindnes: truely
Good boy, I would vpon my faith thy harmelesse
Innocense mooues me at heart, wilt thou goe
Saue thy selfe, why doest thou weepe? Alas I doe not chide thee.

sp.speaker: Urania.
sp.p: I cannot tell if I goe from you, Syr I shall nere dawne day more: Pray if you can I will bee true To you: Let mee waite on you: If I were a man, I would fight for you: Sure you haue some ill-willers, I would slay vm.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Such harmelesse soules are euer Prophets, well I take thy wish, thou shalt be with mee still: But prithee eate, then my good Boy: Thou wilt die my childe If thou fasts one day more. This foure dayes thou hast tasted nothing: Goe into the Caue and eate: Thou shalt finde something for thee, to bring thy bloud agen, and thy faire collour.

lg.l: I can not eate God thanke you,
But Ile eate to morrow.
Thow't bee dead by that time.
I should be well then, for you will not loue me.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Indeed I will. This is the prettiest passion that ere I felt yet: why dost you looke so earnestly vpon me?

lg.l: You haue fayre eyes Master.
Sure the Boy dotes: why dost thou sigh my childe?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: To thinke that such a fine man should liue, and no gay Lady loue him.

lg.l: Thou wilt loue me?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Yes sure till I dye, and when I am in heauen Ile eene wish for you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: And Ile come to thee Boy. This is a loue I neuer yet heard tell of: come, thou art sleepy childe, goe in; and Ile sit with thee: heauen what portends this?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: You are sad, but I am not sleepy, woulde I could doe ought to make you merry: shall I sing?

lg.l: If thou wilt good Boy.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Alas my boy, that thou shouldst comfort me, and art farre worse then I:
sp.stage: Enter Timantus with a letter disguised.

lg.l: Lawe Master, theres one, looke to your sen.
What art thou, that in this dismall place,
Which nothing could finde out but misery,
Thus boldly stept? Comfort was neuer here,
Here is nor foode, nor beds, nor any house
Built by a better Architect then beasts;
And ere you get dwelling from one of them,
You must fight for it: if you conquer him,
He is your meate; if not, you must be his.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I come to you (for if I not mistake, you are the Prince) from that most Noble Lord Ismenus with a Letter.

lg.l: Alas, I feare I shall be discouered now.

sp.speaker: Leu.

lg.l: Now I feele my selfe the poorest of all mortall things.
Where is he that reciues such courtesies,
But he has meanes to shew his gratefulnes
Some way or other? I haue none at all:
I know not how to speake so much as well
Of thee but to these trees.

sp.stage: Leucippus opening the Letter, the whilst Timantus runnes at him, and Vrania steppes before.

lg.l: His Letters speake him sir—

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Gods keepe me but fro knowing him till I dye: aye me, sure I cannot liue a day, ô thou foule Traytor: How doe you Master?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: How dost thou my childe? alas, looke on his, it may make thee repentant, to behold those innocent drops that thou hast drawne from thence.

lg.l: Tis nothing sir and you be well.
O pardon me, know you me now sir?
How couldst thou finde me out?

sp.speaker: Tima.
sp.p:
We intercepted a Letter from Ismenus, and
the bearer directed me.

lg.l: Stand vp Timantus boldly,
The world conceiues that thou art guilty
Of diuers treasons to the State and me:
But ô farre be it from the innocence
Of a iust man to giue a traytor death
Without a tryall: here thy Country is not
To purge thee or condemne thee; therefore
A nobler tryall then thou dost deserue,
Rather then none at all, here I accuse thee
Before the face of heauen, to be a traytor
Both to the Duke my father and to me, and the
Whole Land: speake, is it so or no?
Tis true sir, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Take heed Timantus how thou dost cast away thy selfe, I must proceede to execution hastily if thou confesse it: speake once againe, ist so or no?

sp.speaker: Tim.

lg.l: I am not guilty sir.

sp.stage: Fight here: the Prince gets his sword and giues it him.

lg.l: Gods and thy sword acquit thee, here it is.
I will not vse any violence against your Highnesse.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: At thy perill then, for this must be thy tryall: and from hence forth looke to thy selfe.
sp.stage: Timantus drawes his sword, and runnes at him when he turnes aside.

lg.l: I doe beseech you sir let me not fight.
Vp, vp againe Timantus,
There is no way but this beleeue me.
Now if— Fye, fie Timantus, is there no
Vsage can recouer thee from basenesse? wert thou
Longer to conuerse with men, I would haue chidde
Thee for this: be all thy faults for giuen.
O spare me sir, I am not fit for death.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p:
I thinke thou art not; yet trust me, fitter then
for life: Yet tell mee ere my breath be gone, knowst of any other plots against me?

lg.l: Of none.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What course wouldst thou haue taken when thou hadst kild me?

lg.l: I would hane tane your Page, and maried her.
What Page?
Your boy there.— Dyes.
Is he falne mad in death, what does he meane?
Some good God help me at the worst: how dost thou?
Let not thy misery vexe me, thou shalt haue
What thy poore heart can wish: I am a Prince.
And I will keepe thee in the gayest cloathes,
And the finest things, that euer pretty boy had giuen him.
I know you well enough,
Feth I am dying, and now you know all too.
But stir vp thy selfe; looke what a Iewell here is,
See how it glisters: what a pretty shew
Will this make in thy little eare? ha, speake,
Eate but a bit, and take it.
Doe you not know me?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I prethee minde thy health: why thats well sayd my good boy, smile still.

lg.l: I shall smile till death an I see you.
I am Vrania your sister-in-law.
How!
I am Vrania.
Dulnesse did ceaze me, now I know thee well;
Alas why camst thou hither?

sp.speaker: Vra.
sp.p: Feth for loue, I would not let you know till I was dying; for you could not loue mee, my Mother was so naught.

lg.l: I will loue thee, or any thing: what? wilt
Thou leaue me as soone as I know thee?
Speake one word to me: alas shees past it,
She will nere speake more.
What noyse is that? it is no matter who
Comes on me now. What worse then mad are you
That seeke out sorrowes? if you loue delights
Be gone from hence.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Syr, for you we come, as Souldiers to reuenge the wrongs you haue suffered vnder this naughtie Creature: what shall bee done with her? say, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Leaue her to heauen braue Cousen, they shall tell her how she has sind against em, my hand shall neuer be staind with such base bloud: liue wicked Mother, that reuerent title bee your pardon, for I will vse no extremitie against you, but leaue you to heauen.

lg.l: Hell take you all, if there be a place
Of torment that exceedes that, get you thither:
And till the diuels haue you, may your liues
Be one continued plague, and such a one,
That knowes no friends nor ending.
May all ages that shall succeede curse you as I doe:
And if it be possible, I aske it heauen,
That your base issues may be euer Monsters,
That must for shame of nature and succession,
Be drownd like dogs
Would I had breath to please you.
Would you had loue within you, and such
Griefe as might become a Mother: looke you there,
Know you that face, that was Vrania:
These are the fruits of those vnhappy Mothers,
That labour with such horrid byrths as you doe:
If you can weepe, theres cause; poore innocent,
Your wickednes has kild her: Ile weepe for you.
Monstrous woman,
Mars would weepe at this, and yet she cannot.
Here lies your Minion too, slaine by my hand,
I will not say you are the cause: yet certaine,
I know you were too blame, the Gods forgiue you.
See, she stands as if she were inuenting
Some new destruction for the world.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ismenus, thou art welcome yet to my sad companie.

lg.l: I come to make you somewhat sadder sir.
You cannot, I am at the height already.
Your Fathers dead.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I thought so, heauen be with him: ô woman, woman, weepe now or neuer, thou hast made more sorrowes then we haue eyes to vtter.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Now let heauen fall, I am at the worst of euils, a thing so miserable wretched, that euery thing, the last of humane comforts hath left me: I will not bee so base and colde, to liue and wayte the mercies of these men I hate: no, tis iust I dye, since Fortune hath left me my step discent attends me: hand, strike thou home, I haue soule enough to guide; and let all know, as I stood a Queene, the same Ile fall, and one with me.
sp.stage: She stabs the Prince with a knife.

lg.l: Ho.
How doe you sir?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Neerer my health, then I thinke any here, my tongue begins to faulter: what is man? or who would be one, when he sees a poore weake woman can in an instant make him none.

lg.l: She is dead already.

sp.speaker: Isme.
sp.p: Let her be damnd already as she is: post all for Surgeants.

lg.l: Let not a man sturre, for I am but dead:
I haue some few words which I wold haue you heart,
And am afrayd I shall want breath to speake em:
First to you my Lords, You know Ismenus is
Vndoubtedly heyre of Licia, I doe beseech you all,
When I am dead to shew your duties to him.
We vow to do't.
I thanke you.
Next to you Couzen Ismenus, that shall be the Duke,
I pray you let the broken Image of Cupid
Be reedified, I know all this is done by him.
It shall be so.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Last, I beseech you that my Mother-in-Law may haue a buriall acording to— Dyes.

lg.l: To what sir?
There is a full point.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: I will interpret for him; she shal haue buriall according to her owne deserts, with dogs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I would your Maiestie would haste for setling of the people.

lg.l: I am ready.
Agenor, goe and let the Trumpets sound
Some mournefull thing, whilst we conuey the body
Of this vnhappy Prince vnto the Court,
And of that vertuous Virgin to a graue:
But dragge her to a ditch, where let her lye
Accurst, whilst one man has a memory.

lg.head: Cupids Speech.
lg.l: The time now of my Reuenge drawes neere;
Nor shall it lessen, as I am a god,
With all the cryes and prayers that haue beene;
And those that be to come, tho they be infinite,
In neede and number.
